The ambiance is dark and seedy which I dig, BUT I will say the drinks were poorly executed and the bartender had to look up he ingredients for every drink she made right in front of me, she may have been new but I could definitely tell she didn't know how to make them as they weren't great and she was kinda gruff. I think if I had a better bartender I would have given this place another star. Hope y'all have a better experience than me but definitely worth at least one visit.
Quincy makes the best drinks! Raspberry lemonade and aperol spritz. Great place to spend with your friends!
I'm not sure how their bartenders are unaware of what a french martini is. The condescending tone that was used to tell me that a french martini wasn't actually a martini was not at all appreciated.
Great vibe and a hidden gem behind a bookcase in a hostel. Great drinks and love the atmosphere! A must stop when in Austin.

What an AWESOME Place just off 6th street.  Firehouse was recommended to me on a recent Austin visit.  It's a great speakeasy bar having to enter through a fake bookcase which is awesome.  Once inside, you feel like family.  Both Bradley and Paul took great care of my party.  The drinks were exceptional.  So glad to have found this place and cannot wait to return on my next Austin visit.

We had a fantastic time!! The ambiance was awesome and the drinks were delicious! Our bartender, Bradley, was attentive and friendly.When I told him what I liked he made a drink for me from off the menu-nailed it!! Pony down was delicious 'n
Cool vibe, nice people. Great drinks, lovely speakeasy. Would recommend!! I was there twice had an amazing time , bartenders are cool , drinks are great would def go back

Drinks are fantastic.  They are classic cocktails made perfectly.  The bartender created a drink from listening to me that was perfect.  Ambience is hole in the wall meets hipster but I'm sure it is packed on weekends.
Speakeasy with a bookshelf for a door inside a hostel.  Cool vibes and a good spot for a few low-key drinks after dinner.

Like most Austin locals, I avoid sixth street bars like the plague.  But when out of town friends visit insistent on dirty 6th, we convince them to do a "walk through" of the street before venturing away from the chaos into our favorite little nook - Firehouse Lounge!  Nothing says grungy speakeasy quite like pushing aside a bookcase in the lobby of a hostel.  I'm a fan of their extended happy hour until 8pm and their Moscow mules.  The place tends to get a little crowded on weekends and the line to get drinks can be time consuming so visit on off hours for the best experience.

Bradleeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeey.When you plop a seat down at the bar and the bartender remembers you (fondly), you know you've found a good bar. I've felt all kinda welcome on both visits and I like that they focus on the classics (gimlet, Manhattan, daiquiri, Old Fashioned). They do some have original cocktails, too, as well as beer and wine, but it's a classics bar all the way.Happy hour is until 8pm with $2 off all drinks."Secret" entrance through a bookcase via a hostel, plenty of seating, and dark lighting make this a great spot to take visitors but also to become a regular.No table service; order everything at the bar.

It takes a lot for me to write a negative review.  In fact it took me 3 days of contemplating.  On Saturday night my boy friend and I brought my cousin, her boy friend and uncle (from out of town) to the firehouse lounge.  My cousin specially picked this lounge as she found it was the 2nd best bar in the sixth street area online.  We stood and waiting in front of two empty bar stools for Service.  There were about 2-3 bar tenders working Saturday night when we were there.  These bar tenders completely ignored us as we were waiting 10 mins for service - as they stood around avoiding eye contact at times.  We ultimately decided to leave, not spending a dime here.  As a local Austin native, I was horribly embarrassed by the lack of service we received - especially with out of town guests.  This experience left an awful taste in my mouth - one that keeps reoccurring each time I think about this experience. This isn't the Austin I knew and grew up in.  I have been to the fire house lounge before to enjoy a few live bands.  I don't think I will be back.

If you love a good dive bar and are looking for a unique experience, you have found the right place! Firehouse Lounge is a great place to meet people from all over the world because above the bar is an actual hostel. Plus who doesn't love a hidden entrance! Walk in and slide the bookcase and that is where you will find the bar. Good vibes, good service, good peeps!!

Y'all know I love a good speakeasy! So of course when I was in Austin I had to check this place out. I really loved that this one was hidden in a hostel, behind a book shelf. That was all new for me. I can't recall the name of the first drink I had but I remember the prices being very reasonable! A lot of the time you go to these "exclusive, hiding, or speakeasy" type bars and they want to put crazy prices on their drinks because of it. There were to young men behind they are, they were super friendly, really speedy, knowledgeable, and fun to talk to. We ended up squeezing 2 high top tables together and our group of 9 girls really had a great time here! We took a group picture on the stage and no one made a fuss about it. So glad this is the bar we decided to end our trip on. It really made our experience fun and different!
This is a fancy yet cozy spot! I bought a round of lemon drop shots which were affordable. When you are outside, it feels like you are at a house party around a fire!

This bar is great. I didn't know what to expect but I love the prohibition style theme of this place. Move the bookcase to enter this venue. It had such a retro feel that is so fun. I love the drinks menu and and the interior aesthetic! There is also a small stage for live music too! Such a fun spot!!
Love this hidden gem (pun intended). Great cocktails and always friendly staff!

Wow - this place had a great place in my heart until today. My girlfriend fell trying to get a glass of water, which was inexplicably on a stairway. She didn't see it and took a tumble. Our fault, no big deal, so I went to the bar to get a glass of water. I stood in line patiently for 10 minutes. The drinks here take a long time to make, I get that. Then I was at the bar and noticed the barback wasn't busy and I tried to get his attention - obviously anyone can get me a glass of water. What was the response? The bar tender told me not to talk to him. Then he says "do you want his number or something? Hey what's your number this guy wants your number?" He also added some homophobic slurs that I won't repeat. What???? That's the most insane response ever. Tossing aside how homophobic that is, how is that the response there? That's the most absurd thing anyone has ever said to me. I told them they're out of water and that's what I was asking for. Begrudgingly the bar back gets me a glass of iceless water. Not the hardest thing in the world, but he decided I needed to be slurred in the process. The guy who decided to say I needed to get someone's number instead of a glass of water was wearing a red hat, grey shirt, beard, and it said damn on it. He didn't give me his name but if I get a picture I will update. Stay away especially if you're part of the lgbtq community.

KEEP THE DANG DOOR CLOSED. 90% of the fun here is bringing your friends here and sliding the "secret passageway". So when the door is already left half open it takes away from the experience. I wish the staff here cared more about keeping the door shut when you're entering. Other than the decor this place is just a regular bar with expensive cocktails. It gets overly crowded and noisy and the "speakeasy" atmosphere gets lost in it.That being said it is a fun time and every time we have guests from out of town this place is in the back of mind to take them to.

Nolan and his team were exceptional. Tiki drinks were top notch with creative flare.  Reasonable pricing for tiki drinks and a nice variety to choose from the menu. Very chill and laid back attitude from the staff. Thank you Lost Lei!

Went here to celebrate my birthday with friends. It had just recently opened and thought it would be a great place to go for happy hour. We were right! They had 1/2 price drinks till 7 p.m and they were so good! Bartenders were still learning, but had great suggestions on what to try. Will definitely be back next time I'm in Austin!

My husband and I were in town for one night after moving our son into college. This was near our hotel and we were excited because we've been to tiki bars in other cities and they were always so fun. As we were starting to walk down the stairs (it's underground) we were stopped and asked for our ID. I'll be 50 next month, so I should've been flattered, but I'm guessing everyone has to show their ID as it kind of had a club feel when we walked in. There was a DJ playing Sir Mix a Lot - Baby Got Back. I should've felt at home since that was from back in my day, but wasn't the tiki vibe we were hoping for. We were pleasantly surprised to find a couple seats on a Friday night at 9:30ish, sat down, and waited and waited. No one came to wait on us. Employees passed us a few times and no one acknowledged us. My husband was about to go up to the bar when a worker walked by again and asked if we were good (we must have looked confused or annoyed). We asked about ordering and he said you have to go up to the bar to order.  We both got a mai tai, which was ok, listened to some Fergie and Gwen Stefani playing, and were on our way. It wasn't bad, but definitely not like other tiki bars we've been to.
If you love tiki bars this place doesn't disappoint. The selection of rum is great. The drinks are authentic and their tiki mugs are awesome!

Wanted to like this place. Finally a tiki bar in Austin! They have a great underground location, they have their own personalized tiki mugs and swizzle sticks, and the drinks are decent. Flavors were good, though they didn't seem as strong as other tiki drinks I've had. Also I know tiki drinks are complicated but service seemed really slow for how not busy they were on a Friday.Tables are all pretty small (only seat about 4) so if you have a bigger group you'll have to pull tables together or some will have to stand. Makes me feel really awkward to rearrange bar furniture. The atmosphere of this place is really lacking. It feels like they really went halfassed on the decor. Are they hoping to add more as they go? Very modern walls with no decorations, about six nautical type lights hung from the ceiling, and a grass skirt over the bar. You'll notice every picture on instagram is in front of their skull columns because that's the only thing vaguely tiki about it. So much more could be done with this space to make it a real tiki experience and it was pretty disappointing to walk into. Plus they had a DJ spinning loud top 40s hits - like you'd want in a 6th Street club, not adding to the tiki atmosphere at all. I would love to see a little more design put into the menus as well. Menu currently is just a list with no illustrations. I had to ask other groups for their menu both times I ordered because there didn't seem to be enough copies floating around the bar.

Having learned there was a new tiki bar in Austin I was very excited to check it out. My wife and our friends arrived at about 8:00 on a Thursday night. We used the valet parking out front. But they told us they close at 10:00. Why would a valet outside of a bar close that early? But okay we'd figure that out later. The bar is quite large. It's mostly empty. The decor is mostly very modern. Not quite what I was expecting for a tiki bar. It was brightly lit for some reason. Polished floors. Very clean and modern. There is a thatch awning over the bar and two pillars is decorated with skulls. That was the extent of the tiki decor. We sit down at a table and quickly realize there is no table service. Not a big deal because it's not crowded. But if it were this would be a problem. So we go up and order a round. I tried the bar's signature drink the Washed Ashore. It was good but probably 85% ice. For the price I think that was a bit much. Next got a Zombie which was quite good. Finished off with a Hurricane which was just okay. I really want this bar to succeed. The drinks were pretty good but they need to double down on the tiki vibe. The modern look doesn't fit in my opinion. The staff were great. We talked to the manager for a bit and he was really nice.Definitely worth checking out.

At last a tiki bar that serves strong Polynesian style cocktails. Lost Lei checked all the boxes for me. It is dark, cool, has great service, and  strong, slap yo mama in da butt cocktails.  Is it campy yes...check out the plastic skulls adorning the pillars. Are the drinks sugary, yes, but in Rome. Have I had better, yes, but not in Austin. At the recommendation of our "reasoning for partying gal" we gave this place a shot. We all had their Zombie drink and yes the one drink per person limit is more than reasonable. The bartender was free pouring pretty heavy and I said here comes a tiki-style Long Island ice tea cocktail.Well, or drinks arrived in tall tiki glasses garnished with spearmint. Most likely used to cover up the alcohol fumes. I'm sure it was just a coincidence but as we slowly drained our cocktails our conversation became a tad more animated. I'm pretty sure I do not want our photo booth pics posted on the Web. To summarize a cool spot to have a highly/heavily spirited cocktail with your buds. I would highly recommend a one-and-done if you are ordering the Zombie.
Cute hidden spot. The whole place is Hawaiian - tiki themed. Cool spot. Didn't wait to get in the second time. The first time we went around 9 "they were at capacity"

I came across The Lost Lei randomly about a week ago on Yelp and bookmarked it for a future trip downtown. The Lost Lei is located near the Capital Grille on 4th street with a few different entrances. Our party came off of 4th street and walked down the stairs to get inside. My friend, who joined us later, apparently came inside via another entrance. Inside is dimly lite and has skull decorations on the 2-3 pillars. We sat down at a table near the bar, and we grabbed a few drink menus. Everyone decided on the ZOMBIE drink. What is this drink you ask? This drink is about five shots of deliciousness and gets the job done. Not bad for $16. If you want something more mellow maybe try the Pain Killer?Overall a cool chill spot to grab a few drinks. They have a photo booth that allows you to take a few photos with friends, and you can email it to yourself to post on Instagram, Facebook, or twitter.
Happened to walk by this gem as we were headed to another destination and a treasure!  Great service, drinks, and establishment!

I love a good Tiki bar. So during my recent Austin visit, when I passed by the sign for this place near my hotel I had to stop in. They have all the classic mainstay Tiki drinks (Mai Tai, Zombie, Fog Cutter, etc) with great garnishing, and they don't skimp on the potency  Also a full bar for any other concoction you may want. They have a sweet Happy Hour too! Bartenders & the owner are super friendly and will walk you through the drinks as needed. Definitely a must if you like a good, fun drink spot!

This was a fun little tiki bar my friends and I stumbled upon during our visit to Austin. The entrance is at the bottom of a stairwell that starts up on the ground level.We went on a Sunday afternoon, and upon our arrival we were greeted by the staff, who were friendly and really knew their menu. The one thing that struck me potentially as a red flag was that the place was empty. However, this place had just recently opened when we went, so, I kept an open mind. We had two drinks there, and in that span of time, the place picked up a little, maybe 10-15 more people came for sunday-funday.Their drinks are very sweet, which I expected, and they weren't too strong. They were a little overpriced in my opinion.I think the place has potential, but it was not one of my highlights of my trip to Austin.

The good: drinks are very pretty and good.  The bad: this is not a tiki bar, which is sad.  Some skulls, thatch, and drinks in cool glasses do not a tiki bar make.  The owners need to do some research and go all out if they want tiki respect.  Look at Trader Vics old pictures, Tonga Room, Tonga Hut, Mai Kai, etc.  And the decor and music are all off.  I happen to love 70s yacht rock but it's not the vibe for a tiki bar.  There are so many good choices you could play to set yourself apart - hawaiian lounge, kitshy california surf, lounge in general.  And is it a requirement that all the bartenders be big dudes with hipster beards?  All in all this is nothing special and definitely not a tiki bar.  It's just an average downtown bar.  Could improve though, if you go all tiki.

Trader Vic and Don the Beachcomber would be rolling over in their graves..... This is NOT a real tiki bar. Let me repeat that, this is NOT a real tiki bar. If you are a true tiki connoisseur this is not the place for you. This is a 6th street street bar. A funky, trendy 6th street bar. For a regular 6th street bar I'd give this a different rating but for advertising themselves as a tiki bar you get zero stars. Not even close. Nope. Nope. Nope.When I think of "tiki" I think of an "experience" and an atmosphere that is relaxing and soothing, if that's what you are looking for as well then you need to go elsewhere. Here you will be greeted by music so loud that our group couldn't talk talk to each other without screaming but we did get to enjoy the 6th street dance club loud level of music. No problem, I'm here for the drinks we can talk another time or I can text them. Although we were advised to get a reservation we just showed up and sat at a back table.Where do I begin with the drinks? I tried over four of them to make sure I didn't judge this place on one (possibly) incorrectly made drink. They were definitely consistent with all four drinks.They were all terrible.Polynesian Retreat: what in the actual f*** was this drink? Kool aid in a glass. Super sweet and sugary. The sweetness overwhelmed the drink. Mai Tai: I don't know why we ordered this one, it's so hard to make and everyone has their own version. It looked like a real mai tai but didn't taste like one. I only took one sip because I was ready to leave by this point. Nothing about it tasted tiki but maybe had they sold it was as a non tiki drink it could be salvaged.Fog Cutter: Sadness in a glass. One of the few drinks that didn't put me into sugar shock. Tasted completely off. Did they put vodka in this? Who knows. I was just happy I didn't go into a sugar coma. I got hints of lemon, orange, and vodka...? Wasn't very rum forward. Their take on it, I suppose. It did have gin in it as well. Washed Ashore: No comment. You get the point.I used to hate tiki drinks. Why? Because I only knew those tacky 80's versions where everything had that diabetic inducing sweetness with no depth in flavor. All that turned around a few years ago for me when I finally went to some real tiki bars - Three Dots and a Dash, Tiki Ti, Lost Lake, Latitude 29, False Idol, Tonga Hut, Mother of Pearl, etc - you get the point.  I appreciate real tiki bars and how they are all so different and specialize in their own "thing". With that being said, this is not a tiki place even though the drinks sound like tiki drinks. It made me sad that I drove all the way from San Antonio to check this bar out. I'd been looking forward to coming here and finding a real tiki bar close to me but, alas, it was not to be. I should have known better when I was saw dekuyper on their shelves but I wanted to give them a chance. The only fresh juice I saw was lemon and lime juice. Even the process of watching them make the drinks had me wincing - sometimes measuring and other times just free pouring gone wild. Awful tiki drinks. Awful flavors. I wanted to cry at how badly these cocktails were butchered. They are not worth the $12-14 price tag but perhaps for the happy hour prices it's doable (while closing your eyes and ignoring the "tiki" part of the drink and just enjoying them as sweet cocktails then it wouldn't be so bad). I also noticed that a lot of the tiki mugs looked eerily similar to Three Dots and a Dash. I mean if you're making that type of investment for a tiki bar please put more energy into making real tiki drinks. With that being said this place is better suited as a 6th street club-ish bar. They have a cute photo taking station on the wall that a lot of the young patrons enjoyed using. They definitely love Deep Eddy Vodka I saw it being poured in a lot of the drinks so maybe that's really their niche. Looks like I'll still be waiting for Austin to get a real tiki bar...
Happy hour specials weren't bad, but unless the the bartender, is trying to hit on your girlfriend, you are treated like a ghost.

I was in Austin for 6 nights and spent 4 nights at this bar.  One of the coolest, most chill bars in Austin.  I had a couple different drinks, but my favorite by far was The Zombie.  This thing is worth the price of admission.  10/10 would visit this place again next time I am in town.

The bar is a place worth checking out. I was only in Austin for 1 night and spent most of my time here. The staff and owners are extremely friendly. Drinks are yummy and strong. The Zombie will knock you on your butt. We will for sure be back!
In Austin for one night and this was the best place we went. Fantastic drinks, staff could not be more friendly. If you stop in one place for a cocktail maki it the Lost Lei!!!

This is a super fun bar with tasty cocktails and a great vibe. We had the Beach Bum and a Washed Ashore and we loved them both! They came in fun glasses with interesting garnishes. It's a relatively new place and the owner told us they have 7 new drink and some punch bowls being added to the menu in 2 weeks. We can't wait to come back!

Great hide-a-way in the heart of downtown! If the cool vibes and tucked away locale doesn't take you away from it all, the drinks will. This is a special place because of the love and attention the owner and staff put into it. Fun place to go with a friend/partner/date or with a group. Everyone is in a good mood here... hakuna matata!

Nolan and his team were exceptional. Tiki drinks were top notch with creative flare.  Reasonable pricing for tiki drinks and a nice variety to choose from the menu. Very chill and laid back attitude from the staff. Thank you Lost Lei!

Went here to celebrate my birthday with friends. It had just recently opened and thought it would be a great place to go for happy hour. We were right! They had 1/2 price drinks till 7 p.m and they were so good! Bartenders were still learning, but had great suggestions on what to try. Will definitely be back next time I'm in Austin!

I'll be 50 next month, so I should've been flattered, but I'm guessing everyone has to show their ID as it kind of had a club feel when we walked in. We were pleasantly surprised to find a couple seats on a Friday night at 9:30ish, sat down, and waited and waited. No one came to wait on us. Employees passed us a few times and no one acknowledged us. My husband was about to go up to the bar when a worker walked by again and asked if we were good (we must have looked confused or annoyed). We asked about ordering and he said you have to go up to the bar to order.  We both got a mai tai, which was ok, listened to some Fergie and Gwen Stefani playing, and were on our way. It wasn't bad, but definitely not like other tiki bars we've been to.
If you love tiki bars this place doesn't disappoint. The selection of rum is great. The drinks are authentic and their tiki mugs are awesome!

The drinks were pretty good but they need to double down on the tiki vibe. The modern look doesn't fit in my opinion. The staff were great. We talked to the manager for a bit and he was really nice.Definitely worth checking out.

If you are a true tiki connoisseur this is not the place for you. This is a 6th street street bar. A funky, trendy 6th street bar. For a regular 6th street bar I'd give this a different rating but for advertising themselves as a tiki bar you get zero stars. Not even close. Nope. Nope. Nope.When I think of "tiki" I think of an "experience" and an atmosphere that is relaxing and soothing, if that's what you are looking for as well then you need to go elsewhere. Here you will be greeted by music so loud that our group couldn't talk talk to each other without screaming but we did get to enjoy the 6th street dance club loud level of music. No problem, I'm here for the drinks we can talk another time or I can text them. Although we were advised to get a reservation we just showed up and sat at a back table.Where do I begin with the drinks? I tried over four of them to make sure I didn't judge this place on one (possibly) incorrectly made drink. They were definitely consistent with all four drinks.They were all terrible.Polynesian Retreat: what in the actual f*** was this drink? Kool aid in a glass. Super sweet and sugary. The sweetness overwhelmed the drink. Mai Tai: I don't know why we ordered this one, it's so hard to make and everyone has their own version. It looked like a real mai tai but didn't taste like one. I only took one sip because I was ready to leave by this point. Nothing about it tasted tiki but maybe had they sold it was as a non tiki drink it could be salvaged.Fog Cutter: Sadness in a glass. One of the few drinks that didn't put me into sugar shock. Tasted completely off. Did they put vodka in this? Who knows. I was just happy I didn't go into a sugar coma. I got hints of lemon, orange, and vodka...? Wasn't very rum forward. Their take on it, I suppose. It did have gin in it as well. Washed Ashore: No comment. You get the point.I used to hate tiki drinks. Why? Because I only knew those tacky 80's versions where everything had that diabetic inducing sweetness with no depth in flavor. All that turned around a few years ago for me when I finally went to some real tiki bars - Three Dots and a Dash, Tiki Ti, Lost Lake, Latitude 29, False Idol, Tonga Hut, Mother of Pearl, etc - you get the point.  I appreciate real tiki bars and how they are all so different and specialize in their own "thing". With that being said, this is not a tiki place even though the drinks sound like tiki drinks. It made me sad that I drove all the way from San Antonio to check this bar out. I'd been looking forward to coming here and finding a real tiki bar close to me but, alas, it was not to be. I should have known better when I was saw dekuyper on their shelves but I wanted to give them a chance. The only fresh juice I saw was lemon and lime juice. Even the process of watching them make the drinks had me wincing - sometimes measuring and other times just free pouring gone wild. Awful tiki drinks. Awful flavors. I wanted to cry at how badly these cocktails were butchered. They are not worth the $12-14 price tag but perhaps for the happy hour prices it's doable (while closing your eyes and ignoring the "tiki" part of the drink and just enjoying them as sweet cocktails then it wouldn't be so bad). I also noticed that a lot of the tiki mugs looked eerily similar to Three Dots and a Dash. I mean if you're making that type of investment for a tiki bar please put more energy into making real tiki drinks. With that being said this place is better suited as a 6th street club-ish bar. They have a cute photo taking station on the wall that a lot of the young patrons enjoyed using. They definitely love Deep Eddy Vodka I saw it being poured in a lot of the drinks so maybe that's really their niche. Looks like I'll still be waiting for Austin to get a real tiki bar...
Happy hour specials weren't bad, but unless the the bartender, is trying to hit on your girlfriend, you are treated like a ghost.

I was in Austin for 6 nights and spent 4 nights at this bar.  One of the coolest, most chill bars in Austin.  I had a couple different drinks, but my favorite by far was The Zombie.  This thing is worth the price of admission.  10/10 would visit this place again next time I am in town.

The bar is a place worth checking out. I was only in Austin for 1 night and spent most of my time here. The staff and owners are extremely friendly. Drinks are yummy and strong. The Zombie will knock you on your butt. We will for sure be back!
In Austin for one night and this was the best place we went. Fantastic drinks, staff could not be more friendly. If you stop in one place for a cocktail maki it the Lost Lei!!!

This is a super fun bar with tasty cocktails and a great vibe. We had the Beach Bum and a Washed Ashore and we loved them both! They came in fun glasses with interesting garnishes. It's a relatively new place and the owner told us they have 7 new drink and some punch bowls being added to the menu in 2 weeks. We can't wait to come back!

Great hide-a-way in the heart of downtown! If the cool vibes and tucked away locale doesn't take you away from it all, the drinks will. This is a special place because of the love and attention the owner and staff put into it. Fun place to go with a friend/partner/date or with a group. Everyone is in a good mood here... hakuna matata!

Nolan and his team were exceptional. Tiki drinks were top notch with creative flare.  Reasonable pricing for tiki drinks and a nice variety to choose from the menu. Very chill and laid back attitude from the staff. Thank you Lost Lei!

Went here to celebrate my birthday with friends. It had just recently opened and thought it would be a great place to go for happy hour. We were right! They had 1/2 price drinks till 7 p.m and they were so good! Bartenders were still learning, but had great suggestions on what to try. Will definitely be back next time I'm in Austin!

My husband and I were in town for one night after moving our son into college. This was near our hotel and we were excited because we've been to tiki bars in other cities and they were always so fun. As we were starting to walk down the stairs (it's underground) we were stopped and asked for our ID. I'll be 50 next month, so I should've been flattered, but I'm guessing everyone has to show their ID as it kind of had a club feel when we walked in. There was a DJ playing Sir Mix a Lot - Baby Got Back. I should've felt at home since that was from back in my day, but wasn't the tiki vibe we were hoping for. We were pleasantly surprised to find a couple seats on a Friday night at 9:30ish, sat down, and waited and waited. No one came to wait on us. Employees passed us a few times and no one acknowledged us. My husband was about to go up to the bar when a worker walked by again and asked if we were good (we must have looked confused or annoyed). We asked about ordering and he said you have to go up to the bar to order.  We both got a mai tai, which was ok, listened to some Fergie and Gwen Stefani playing, and were on our way. It wasn't bad, but definitely not like other tiki bars we've been to.
If you love tiki bars this place doesn't disappoint. The selection of rum is great. The drinks are authentic and their tiki mugs are awesome!

Wanted to like this place. Finally a tiki bar in Austin! They have a great underground location, they have their own personalized tiki mugs and swizzle sticks, and the drinks are decent. Flavors were good, though they didn't seem as strong as other tiki drinks I've had. Also I know tiki drinks are complicated but service seemed really slow for how not busy they were on a Friday.Tables are all pretty small (only seat about 4) so if you have a bigger group you'll have to pull tables together or some will have to stand. Makes me feel really awkward to rearrange bar furniture. The atmosphere of this place is really lacking. It feels like they really went halfassed on the decor. Are they hoping to add more as they go? Very modern walls with no decorations, about six nautical type lights hung from the ceiling, and a grass skirt over the bar. You'll notice every picture on instagram is in front of their skull columns because that's the only thing vaguely tiki about it. So much more could be done with this space to make it a real tiki experience and it was pretty disappointing to walk into. Plus they had a DJ spinning loud top 40s hits - like you'd want in a 6th Street club, not adding to the tiki atmosphere at all. I would love to see a little more design put into the menus as well. Menu currently is just a list with no illustrations. I had to ask other groups for their menu both times I ordered because there didn't seem to be enough copies floating around the bar.

Having learned there was a new tiki bar in Austin I was very excited to check it out. My wife and our friends arrived at about 8:00 on a Thursday night. We used the valet parking out front. But they told us they close at 10:00. Why would a valet outside of a bar close that early? But okay we'd figure that out later. The bar is quite large. It's mostly empty. The decor is mostly very modern. Not quite what I was expecting for a tiki bar. It was brightly lit for some reason. Polished floors. Very clean and modern. There is a thatch awning over the bar and two pillars is decorated with skulls. That was the extent of the tiki decor. We sit down at a table and quickly realize there is no table service. Not a big deal because it's not crowded. But if it were this would be a problem. So we go up and order a round. I tried the bar's signature drink the Washed Ashore. It was good but probably 85% ice. For the price I think that was a bit much. Next got a Zombie which was quite good. Finished off with a Hurricane which was just okay. I really want this bar to succeed. The drinks were pretty good but they need to double down on the tiki vibe. The modern look doesn't fit in my opinion. The staff were great. We talked to the manager for a bit and he was really nice.Definitely worth checking out.

At last a tiki bar that serves strong Polynesian style cocktails. Lost Lei checked all the boxes for me. It is dark, cool, has great service, and  strong, slap yo mama in da butt cocktails.  Is it campy yes...check out the plastic skulls adorning the pillars. Are the drinks sugary, yes, but in Rome. Have I had better, yes, but not in Austin. At the recommendation of our "reasoning for partying gal" we gave this place a shot. We all had their Zombie drink and yes the one drink per person limit is more than reasonable. The bartender was free pouring pretty heavy and I said here comes a tiki-style Long Island ice tea cocktail.Well, or drinks arrived in tall tiki glasses garnished with spearmint. Most likely used to cover up the alcohol fumes. I'm sure it was just a coincidence but as we slowly drained our cocktails our conversation became a tad more animated. I'm pretty sure I do not want our photo booth pics posted on the Web. To summarize a cool spot to have a highly/heavily spirited cocktail with your buds. I would highly recommend a one-and-done if you are ordering the Zombie.
Cute hidden spot. The whole place is Hawaiian - tiki themed. Cool spot. Didn't wait to get in the second time. The first time we went around 9 "they were at capacity"

I came across The Lost Lei randomly about a week ago on Yelp and bookmarked it for a future trip downtown. The Lost Lei is located near the Capital Grille on 4th street with a few different entrances. Our party came off of 4th street and walked down the stairs to get inside. My friend, who joined us later, apparently came inside via another entrance. Inside is dimly lite and has skull decorations on the 2-3 pillars. We sat down at a table near the bar, and we grabbed a few drink menus. Everyone decided on the ZOMBIE drink. What is this drink you ask? This drink is about five shots of deliciousness and gets the job done. Not bad for $16. If you want something more mellow maybe try the Pain Killer?Overall a cool chill spot to grab a few drinks. They have a photo booth that allows you to take a few photos with friends, and you can email it to yourself to post on Instagram, Facebook, or twitter.
Happened to walk by this gem as we were headed to another destination and a treasure!  Great service, drinks, and establishment!

I love a good Tiki bar. So during my recent Austin visit, when I passed by the sign for this place near my hotel I had to stop in. They have all the classic mainstay Tiki drinks (Mai Tai, Zombie, Fog Cutter, etc) with great garnishing, and they don't skimp on the potency  Also a full bar for any other concoction you may want. They have a sweet Happy Hour too! Bartenders & the owner are super friendly and will walk you through the drinks as needed. Definitely a must if you like a good, fun drink spot!

This was a fun little tiki bar my friends and I stumbled upon during our visit to Austin. The entrance is at the bottom of a stairwell that starts up on the ground level.We went on a Sunday afternoon, and upon our arrival we were greeted by the staff, who were friendly and really knew their menu. The one thing that struck me potentially as a red flag was that the place was empty. However, this place had just recently opened when we went, so, I kept an open mind. We had two drinks there, and in that span of time, the place picked up a little, maybe 10-15 more people came for sunday-funday.Their drinks are very sweet, which I expected, and they weren't too strong. They were a little overpriced in my opinion.I think the place has potential, but it was not one of my highlights of my trip to Austin.

The good: drinks are very pretty and good.  The bad: this is not a tiki bar, which is sad.  Some skulls, thatch, and drinks in cool glasses do not a tiki bar make.  The owners need to do some research and go all out if they want tiki respect.  Look at Trader Vics old pictures, Tonga Room, Tonga Hut, Mai Kai, etc.  And the decor and music are all off.  I happen to love 70s yacht rock but it's not the vibe for a tiki bar.  There are so many good choices you could play to set yourself apart - hawaiian lounge, kitshy california surf, lounge in general.  And is it a requirement that all the bartenders be big dudes with hipster beards?  All in all this is nothing special and definitely not a tiki bar.  It's just an average downtown bar.  Could improve though, if you go all tiki.

They are not worth the $12-14 price tag but perhaps for the happy hour prices it's doable (while closing your eyes and ignoring the "tiki" part of the drink and just enjoying them as sweet cocktails then it wouldn't be so bad). I also noticed that a lot of the tiki mugs looked eerily similar to Three Dots and a Dash. I mean if you're making that type of investment for a tiki bar please put more energy into making real tiki drinks. With that being said this place is better suited as a 6th street club-ish bar. They have a cute photo taking station on the wall that a lot of the young patrons enjoyed using. They definitely love Deep Eddy Vodka I saw it being poured in a lot of the drinks so maybe that's really their niche. Looks like I'll still be waiting for Austin to get a real tiki bar...
Happy hour specials weren't bad, but unless the the bartender, is trying to hit on your girlfriend, you are treated like a ghost.

I was in Austin for 6 nights and spent 4 nights at this bar.  One of the coolest, most chill bars in Austin.  I had a couple different drinks, but my favorite by far was The Zombie.  This thing is worth the price of admission.  10/10 would visit this place again next time I am in town.

The bar is a place worth checking out. I was only in Austin for 1 night and spent most of my time here. The staff and owners are extremely friendly. Drinks are yummy and strong. The Zombie will knock you on your butt. We will for sure be back!
In Austin for one night and this was the best place we went. Fantastic drinks, staff could not be more friendly. If you stop in one place for a cocktail maki it the Lost Lei!!!

This is a super fun bar with tasty cocktails and a great vibe. We had the Beach Bum and a Washed Ashore and we loved them both! They came in fun glasses with interesting garnishes. It's a relatively new place and the owner told us they have 7 new drink and some punch bowls being added to the menu in 2 weeks. We can't wait to come back!

Great hide-a-way in the heart of downtown! If the cool vibes and tucked away locale doesn't take you away from it all, the drinks will. This is a special place because of the love and attention the owner and staff put into it. Fun place to go with a friend/partner/date or with a group. Everyone is in a good mood here... hakuna matata!

Nolan and his team were exceptional. Tiki drinks were top notch with creative flare.  Reasonable pricing for tiki drinks and a nice variety to choose from the menu. Very chill and laid back attitude from the staff. Thank you Lost Lei!

Went here to celebrate my birthday with friends. It had just recently opened and thought it would be a great place to go for happy hour. We were right! They had 1/2 price drinks till 7 p.m and they were so good! Bartenders were still learning, but had great suggestions on what to try. Will definitely be back next time I'm in Austin!

My husband and I were in town for one night after moving our son into college. This was near our hotel and we were excited because we've been to tiki bars in other cities and they were always so fun. As we were starting to walk down the stairs (it's underground) we were stopped and asked for our ID. I'll be 50 next month, so I should've been flattered, but I'm guessing everyone has to show their ID as it kind of had a club feel when we walked in. There was a DJ playing Sir Mix a Lot - Baby Got Back. I should've felt at home since that was from back in my day, but wasn't the tiki vibe we were hoping for. We were pleasantly surprised to find a couple seats on a Friday night at 9:30ish, sat down, and waited and waited. No one came to wait on us. Employees passed us a few times and no one acknowledged us. My husband was about to go up to the bar when a worker walked by again and asked if we were good (we must have looked confused or annoyed). We asked about ordering and he said you have to go up to the bar to order.  We both got a mai tai, which was ok, listened to some Fergie and Gwen Stefani playing, and were on our way. It wasn't bad, but definitely not like other tiki bars we've been to.
If you love tiki bars this place doesn't disappoint. The selection of rum is great. The drinks are authentic and their tiki mugs are awesome!

Wanted to like this place. Finally a tiki bar in Austin! They have a great underground location, they have their own personalized tiki mugs and swizzle sticks, and the drinks are decent. Flavors were good, though they didn't seem as strong as other tiki drinks I've had. Also I know tiki drinks are complicated but service seemed really slow for how not busy they were on a Friday.Tables are all pretty small (only seat about 4) so if you have a bigger group you'll have to pull tables together or some will have to stand. Makes me feel really awkward to rearrange bar furniture. The atmosphere of this place is really lacking. It feels like they really went halfassed on the decor. Are they hoping to add more as they go? Very modern walls with no decorations, about six nautical type lights hung from the ceiling, and a grass skirt over the bar. You'll notice every picture on instagram is in front of their skull columns because that's the only thing vaguely tiki about it. So much more could be done with this space to make it a real tiki experience and it was pretty disappointing to walk into. Plus they had a DJ spinning loud top 40s hits - like you'd want in a 6th Street club, not adding to the tiki atmosphere at all. I would love to see a little more design put into the menus as well. Menu currently is just a list with no illustrations. I had to ask other groups for their menu both times I ordered because there didn't seem to be enough copies floating around the bar.

Having learned there was a new tiki bar in Austin I was very excited to check it out. My wife and our friends arrived at about 8:00 on a Thursday night. We used the valet parking out front. But they told us they close at 10:00. Why would a valet outside of a bar close that early? But okay we'd figure that out later. The bar is quite large. It's mostly empty. The decor is mostly very modern. Not quite what I was expecting for a tiki bar. It was brightly lit for some reason. Polished floors. Very clean and modern. There is a thatch awning over the bar and two pillars is decorated with skulls. That was the extent of the tiki decor. We sit down at a table and quickly realize there is no table service. Not a big deal because it's not crowded. But if it were this would be a problem. So we go up and order a round. I tried the bar's signature drink the Washed Ashore. It was good but probably 85% ice. For the price I think that was a bit much. Next got a Zombie which was quite good. Finished off with a Hurricane which was just okay. I really want this bar to succeed. The drinks were pretty good but they need to double down on the tiki vibe. The modern look doesn't fit in my opinion. The staff were great. We talked to the manager for a bit and he was really nice.Definitely worth checking out.

At last a tiki bar that serves strong Polynesian style cocktails. Lost Lei checked all the boxes for me. It is dark, cool, has great service, and  strong, slap yo mama in da butt cocktails.  Is it campy yes...check out the plastic skulls adorning the pillars. Are the drinks sugary, yes, but in Rome. Have I had better, yes, but not in Austin. At the recommendation of our "reasoning for partying gal" we gave this place a shot. We all had their Zombie drink and yes the one drink per person limit is more than reasonable. The bartender was free pouring pretty heavy and I said here comes a tiki-style Long Island ice tea cocktail.Well, or drinks arrived in tall tiki glasses garnished with spearmint. Most likely used to cover up the alcohol fumes. I'm sure it was just a coincidence but as we slowly drained our cocktails our conversation became a tad more animated. I'm pretty sure I do not want our photo booth pics posted on the Web. To summarize a cool spot to have a highly/heavily spirited cocktail with your buds. I would highly recommend a one-and-done if you are ordering the Zombie.
Cute hidden spot. The whole place is Hawaiian - tiki themed. Cool spot. Didn't wait to get in the second time. The first time we went around 9 "they were at capacity"

I came across The Lost Lei randomly about a week ago on Yelp and bookmarked it for a future trip downtown. The Lost Lei is located near the Capital Grille on 4th street with a few different entrances. Our party came off of 4th street and walked down the stairs to get inside. My friend, who joined us later, apparently came inside via another entrance. Inside is dimly lite and has skull decorations on the 2-3 pillars. We sat down at a table near the bar, and we grabbed a few drink menus. Everyone decided on the ZOMBIE drink. What is this drink you ask? This drink is about five shots of deliciousness and gets the job done. Not bad for $16. If you want something more mellow maybe try the Pain Killer?Overall a cool chill spot to grab a few drinks. They have a photo booth that allows you to take a few photos with friends, and you can email it to yourself to post on Instagram, Facebook, or twitter.
Happened to walk by this gem as we were headed to another destination and a treasure!  Great service, drinks, and establishment!

I love a good Tiki bar. So during my recent Austin visit, when I passed by the sign for this place near my hotel I had to stop in. They have all the classic mainstay Tiki drinks (Mai Tai, Zombie, Fog Cutter, etc) with great garnishing, and they don't skimp on the potency  Also a full bar for any other concoction you may want. They have a sweet Happy Hour too! Bartenders & the owner are super friendly and will walk you through the drinks as needed. Definitely a must if you like a good, fun drink spot!

This was a fun little tiki bar my friends and I stumbled upon during our visit to Austin. The entrance is at the bottom of a stairwell that starts up on the ground level.We went on a Sunday afternoon, and upon our arrival we were greeted by the staff, who were friendly and really knew their menu. The one thing that struck me potentially as a red flag was that the place was empty. However, this place had just recently opened when we went, so, I kept an open mind. We had two drinks there, and in that span of time, the place picked up a little, maybe 10-15 more people came for sunday-funday.Their drinks are very sweet, which I expected, and they weren't too strong. They were a little overpriced in my opinion.I think the place has potential, but it was not one of my highlights of my trip to Austin.

The good: drinks are very pretty and good.  The bad: this is not a tiki bar, which is sad.  Some skulls, thatch, and drinks in cool glasses do not a tiki bar make.  The owners need to do some research and go all out if they want tiki respect.  Look at Trader Vics old pictures, Tonga Room, Tonga Hut, Mai Kai, etc.  And the decor and music are all off.  I happen to love 70s yacht rock but it's not the vibe for a tiki bar.  There are so many good choices you could play to set yourself apart - hawaiian lounge, kitshy california surf, lounge in general.  And is it a requirement that all the bartenders be big dudes with hipster beards?  All in all this is nothing special and definitely not a tiki bar.  It's just an average downtown bar.  Could improve though, if you go all tiki.

Trader Vic and Don the Beachcomber would be rolling over in their graves..... This is NOT a real tiki bar. Let me repeat that, this is NOT a real tiki bar. If you are a true tiki connoisseur this is not the place for you. This is a 6th street street bar. A funky, trendy 6th street bar. For a regular 6th street bar I'd give this a different rating but for advertising themselves as a tiki bar you get zero stars. Not even close. Nope. Nope. Nope.When I think of "tiki" I think of an "experience" and an atmosphere that is relaxing and soothing, if that's what you are looking for as well then you need to go elsewhere. Here you will be greeted by music so loud that our group couldn't talk talk to each other without screaming but we did get to enjoy the 6th street dance club loud level of music. No problem, I'm here for the drinks we can talk another time or I can text them. Although we were advised to get a reservation we just showed up and sat at a back table.Where do I begin with the drinks? I tried over four of them to make sure I didn't judge this place on one (possibly) incorrectly made drink. They were definitely consistent with all four drinks.They were all terrible.Polynesian Retreat: what in the actual f*** was this drink? Kool aid in a glass. Super sweet and sugary. The sweetness overwhelmed the drink. Mai Tai: I don't know why we ordered this one, it's so hard to make and everyone has their own version. It looked like a real mai tai but didn't taste like one. I only took one sip because I was ready to leave by this point. Nothing about it tasted tiki but maybe had they sold it was as a non tiki drink it could be salvaged.Fog Cutter: Sadness in a glass. One of the few drinks that didn't put me into sugar shock. Tasted completely off. Did they put vodka in this? Who knows. I was just happy I didn't go into a sugar coma. I got hints of lemon, orange, and vodka...? Wasn't very rum forward. Their take on it, I suppose. It did have gin in it as well. Washed Ashore: No comment. You get the point.I used to hate tiki drinks. Why? Because I only knew those tacky 80's versions where everything had that diabetic inducing sweetness with no depth in flavor. All that turned around a few years ago for me when I finally went to some real tiki bars - Three Dots and a Dash, Tiki Ti, Lost Lake, Latitude 29, False Idol, Tonga Hut, Mother of Pearl, etc - you get the point.  I appreciate real tiki bars and how they are all so different and specialize in their own "thing". With that being said, this is not a tiki place even though the drinks sound like tiki drinks. It made me sad that I drove all the way from San Antonio to check this bar out. I'd been looking forward to coming here and finding a real tiki bar close to me but, alas, it was not to be. I should have known better when I was saw dekuyper on their shelves but I wanted to give them a chance. The only fresh juice I saw was lemon and lime juice. Even the process of watching them make the drinks had me wincing - sometimes measuring and other times just free pouring gone wild. Awful tiki drinks. Awful flavors. I wanted to cry at how badly these cocktails were butchered. They are not worth the $12-14 price tag but perhaps for the happy hour prices it's doable (while closing your eyes and ignoring the "tiki" part of the drink and just enjoying them as sweet cocktails then it wouldn't be so bad). I also noticed that a lot of the tiki mugs looked eerily similar to Three Dots and a Dash. I mean if you're making that type of investment for a tiki bar please put more energy into making real tiki drinks. With that being said this place is better suited as a 6th street club-ish bar. They have a cute photo taking station on the wall that a lot of the young patrons enjoyed using. They definitely love Deep Eddy Vodka I saw it being poured in a lot of the drinks so maybe that's really their niche. Looks like I'll still be waiting for Austin to get a real tiki bar...
Happy hour specials weren't bad, but unless the the bartender, is trying to hit on your girlfriend, you are treated like a ghost.

Went here to celebrate my birthday with friends. It had just recently opened and thought it would be a great place to go for happy hour. We were right! They had 1/2 price drinks till 7 p.m and they were so good! Bartenders were still learning, but had great suggestions on what to try. Will definitely be back next time I'm in Austin!

My husband and I were in town for one night after moving our son into college. This was near our hotel and we were excited because we've been to tiki bars in other cities and they were always so fun. As we were starting to walk down the stairs (it's underground) we were stopped and asked for our ID. I'll be 50 next month, so I should've been flattered, but I'm guessing everyone has to show their ID as it kind of had a club feel when we walked in. There was a DJ playing Sir Mix a Lot - Baby Got Back. I should've felt at home since that was from back in my day, but wasn't the tiki vibe we were hoping for. We were pleasantly surprised to find a couple seats on a Friday night at 9:30ish, sat down, and waited and waited. No one came to wait on us. Employees passed us a few times and no one acknowledged us. My husband was about to go up to the bar when a worker walked by again and asked if we were good (we must have looked confused or annoyed). We asked about ordering and he said you have to go up to the bar to order.  We both got a mai tai, which was ok, listened to some Fergie and Gwen Stefani playing, and were on our way. It wasn't bad, but definitely not like other tiki bars we've been to.
If you love tiki bars this place doesn't disappoint. The selection of rum is great. The drinks are authentic and their tiki mugs are awesome!

Wanted to like this place. Finally a tiki bar in Austin! They have a great underground location, they have their own personalized tiki mugs and swizzle sticks, and the drinks are decent. Flavors were good, though they didn't seem as strong as other tiki drinks I've had. Also I know tiki drinks are complicated but service seemed really slow for how not busy they were on a Friday.Tables are all pretty small (only seat about 4) so if you have a bigger group you'll have to pull tables together or some will have to stand. Makes me feel really awkward to rearrange bar furniture. The atmosphere of this place is really lacking. It feels like they really went halfassed on the decor. Are they hoping to add more as they go? Very modern walls with no decorations, about six nautical type lights hung from the ceiling, and a grass skirt over the bar. You'll notice every picture on instagram is in front of their skull columns because that's the only thing vaguely tiki about it. So much more could be done with this space to make it a real tiki experience and it was pretty disappointing to walk into. Plus they had a DJ spinning loud top 40s hits - like you'd want in a 6th Street club, not adding to the tiki atmosphere at all. I would love to see a little more design put into the menus as well. Menu currently is just a list with no illustrations. I had to ask other groups for their menu both times I ordered because there didn't seem to be enough copies floating around the bar.

Having learned there was a new tiki bar in Austin I was very excited to check it out. My wife and our friends arrived at about 8:00 on a Thursday night. We used the valet parking out front. But they told us they close at 10:00. Why would a valet outside of a bar close that early? But okay we'd figure that out later. The bar is quite large. It's mostly empty. The decor is mostly very modern. Not quite what I was expecting for a tiki bar. It was brightly lit for some reason. Polished floors. Very clean and modern. There is a thatch awning over the bar and two pillars is decorated with skulls. That was the extent of the tiki decor. We sit down at a table and quickly realize there is no table service. Not a big deal because it's not crowded. But if it were this would be a problem. So we go up and order a round. I tried the bar's signature drink the Washed Ashore. It was good but probably 85% ice. For the price I think that was a bit much. Next got a Zombie which was quite good. Finished off with a Hurricane which was just okay. I really want this bar to succeed. The drinks were pretty good but they need to double down on the tiki vibe. The modern look doesn't fit in my opinion. The staff were great. We talked to the manager for a bit and he was really nice.Definitely worth checking out.

At last a tiki bar that serves strong Polynesian style cocktails. Lost Lei checked all the boxes for me. It is dark, cool, has great service, and  strong, slap yo mama in da butt cocktails.  Is it campy yes...check out the plastic skulls adorning the pillars. Are the drinks sugary, yes, but in Rome. Have I had better, yes, but not in Austin. At the recommendation of our "reasoning for partying gal" we gave this place a shot. We all had their Zombie drink and yes the one drink per person limit is more than reasonable. The bartender was free pouring pretty heavy and I said here comes a tiki-style Long Island ice tea cocktail.Well, or drinks arrived in tall tiki glasses garnished with spearmint. Most likely used to cover up the alcohol fumes. I'm sure it was just a coincidence but as we slowly drained our cocktails our conversation became a tad more animated. I'm pretty sure I do not want our photo booth pics posted on the Web. To summarize a cool spot to have a highly/heavily spirited cocktail with your buds. I would highly recommend a one-and-done if you are ordering the Zombie.
Cute hidden spot. The whole place is Hawaiian - tiki themed. Cool spot. Didn't wait to get in the second time. The first time we went around 9 "they were at capacity"

I came across The Lost Lei randomly about a week ago on Yelp and bookmarked it for a future trip downtown. The Lost Lei is located near the Capital Grille on 4th street with a few different entrances. Our party came off of 4th street and walked down the stairs to get inside. My friend, who joined us later, apparently came inside via another entrance. Inside is dimly lite and has skull decorations on the 2-3 pillars. We sat down at a table near the bar, and we grabbed a few drink menus. Everyone decided on the ZOMBIE drink. What is this drink you ask? This drink is about five shots of deliciousness and gets the job done. Not bad for $16. If you want something more mellow maybe try the Pain Killer?Overall a cool chill spot to grab a few drinks. They have a photo booth that allows you to take a few photos with friends, and you can email it to yourself to post on Instagram, Facebook, or twitter.
Happened to walk by this gem as we were headed to another destination and a treasure!  Great service, drinks, and establishment!

I love a good Tiki bar. So during my recent Austin visit, when I passed by the sign for this place near my hotel I had to stop in. They have all the classic mainstay Tiki drinks (Mai Tai, Zombie, Fog Cutter, etc) with great garnishing, and they don't skimp on the potency  Also a full bar for any other concoction you may want. They have a sweet Happy Hour too! Bartenders & the owner are super friendly and will walk you through the drinks as needed. Definitely a must if you like a good, fun drink spot!

This was a fun little tiki bar my friends and I stumbled upon during our visit to Austin. The entrance is at the bottom of a stairwell that starts up on the ground level.We went on a Sunday afternoon, and upon our arrival we were greeted by the staff, who were friendly and really knew their menu. The one thing that struck me potentially as a red flag was that the place was empty. However, this place had just recently opened when we went, so, I kept an open mind. We had two drinks there, and in that span of time, the place picked up a little, maybe 10-15 more people came for sunday-funday.Their drinks are very sweet, which I expected, and they weren't too strong. They were a little overpriced in my opinion.I think the place has potential, but it was not one of my highlights of my trip to Austin.

The good: drinks are very pretty and good.  The bad: this is not a tiki bar, which is sad.  Some skulls, thatch, and drinks in cool glasses do not a tiki bar make.  The owners need to do some research and go all out if they want tiki respect.  Look at Trader Vics old pictures, Tonga Room, Tonga Hut, Mai Kai, etc.  And the decor and music are all off.  I happen to love 70s yacht rock but it's not the vibe for a tiki bar.  There are so many good choices you could play to set yourself apart - hawaiian lounge, kitshy california surf, lounge in general.  And is it a requirement that all the bartenders be big dudes with hipster beards?  All in all this is nothing special and definitely not a tiki bar.  It's just an average downtown bar.  Could improve though, if you go all tiki.

Trader Vic and Don the Beachcomber would be rolling over in their graves..... This is NOT a real tiki bar. Let me repeat that, this is NOT a real tiki bar. If you are a true tiki connoisseur this is not the place for you. This is a 6th street street bar. A funky, trendy 6th street bar. For a regular 6th street bar I'd give this a different rating but for advertising themselves as a tiki bar you get zero stars. Not even close. Nope. Nope. Nope.When I think of "tiki" I think of an "experience" and an atmosphere that is relaxing and soothing, if that's what you are looking for as well then you need to go elsewhere. Here you will be greeted by music so loud that our group couldn't talk talk to each other without screaming but we did get to enjoy the 6th street dance club loud level of music. No problem, I'm here for the drinks we can talk another time or I can text them. Although we were advised to get a reservation we just showed up and sat at a back table.Where do I begin with the drinks? I tried over four of them to make sure I didn't judge this place on one (possibly) incorrectly made drink. They were definitely consistent with all four drinks.They were all terrible.Polynesian Retreat: what in the actual f*** was this drink? Kool aid in a glass. Super sweet and sugary. The sweetness overwhelmed the drink. Mai Tai: I don't know why we ordered this one, it's so hard to make and everyone has their own version. It looked like a real mai tai but didn't taste like one. I only took one sip because I was ready to leave by this point. Nothing about it tasted tiki but maybe had they sold it was as a non tiki drink it could be salvaged.Fog Cutter: Sadness in a glass. One of the few drinks that didn't put me into sugar shock. Tasted completely off. Did they put vodka in this? Who knows. I was just happy I didn't go into a sugar coma. I got hints of lemon, orange, and vodka...? Wasn't very rum forward. Their take on it, I suppose. It did have gin in it as well. Washed Ashore: No comment. You get the point.I used to hate tiki drinks. Why? Because I only knew those tacky 80's versions where everything had that diabetic inducing sweetness with no depth in flavor. All that turned around a few years ago for me when I finally went to some real tiki bars - Three Dots and a Dash, Tiki Ti, Lost Lake, Latitude 29, False Idol, Tonga Hut, Mother of Pearl, etc - you get the point.  I appreciate real tiki bars and how they are all so different and specialize in their own "thing". With that being said, this is not a tiki place even though the drinks sound like tiki drinks. It made me sad that I drove all the way from San Antonio to check this bar out. I'd been looking forward to coming here and finding a real tiki bar close to me but, alas, it was not to be. I should have known better when I was saw dekuyper on their shelves but I wanted to give them a chance. The only fresh juice I saw was lemon and lime juice. Even the process of watching them make the drinks had me wincing - sometimes measuring and other times just free pouring gone wild. Awful tiki drinks. Awful flavors. I wanted to cry at how badly these cocktails were butchered. They are not worth the $12-14 price tag but perhaps for the happy hour prices it's doable (while closing your eyes and ignoring the "tiki" part of the drink and just enjoying them as sweet cocktails then it wouldn't be so bad). I also noticed that a lot of the tiki mugs looked eerily similar to Three Dots and a Dash. I mean if you're making that type of investment for a tiki bar please put more energy into making real tiki drinks. With that being said this place is better suited as a 6th street club-ish bar. They have a cute photo taking station on the wall that a lot of the young patrons enjoyed using. They definitely love Deep Eddy Vodka I saw it being poured in a lot of the drinks so maybe that's really their niche. Looks like I'll still be waiting for Austin to get a real tiki bar...
Happy hour specials weren't bad, but unless the the bartender, is trying to hit on your girlfriend, you are treated like a ghost.

I was in Austin for 6 nights and spent 4 nights at this bar.  One of the coolest, most chill bars in Austin.  I had a couple different drinks, but my favorite by far was The Zombie.  This thing is worth the price of admission.  10/10 would visit this place again next time I am in town.

The bar is a place worth checking out. I was only in Austin for 1 night and spent most of my time here. The staff and owners are extremely friendly. Drinks are yummy and strong. The Zombie will knock you on your butt. We will for sure be back!
In Austin for one night and this was the best place we went. Fantastic drinks, staff could not be more friendly. If you stop in one place for a cocktail maki it the Lost Lei!!!

This is a super fun bar with tasty cocktails and a great vibe. We had the Beach Bum and a Washed Ashore and we loved them both! They came in fun glasses with interesting garnishes. It's a relatively new place and the owner told us they have 7 new drink and some punch bowls being added to the menu in 2 weeks. We can't wait to come back!

Great hide-a-way in the heart of downtown! If the cool vibes and tucked away locale doesn't take you away from it all, the drinks will. This is a special place because of the love and attention the owner and staff put into it. Fun place to go with a friend/partner/date or with a group. Everyone is in a good mood here... hakuna matata!

Nolan and his team were exceptional. Tiki drinks were top notch with creative flare.  Reasonable pricing for tiki drinks and a nice variety to choose from the menu. Very chill and laid back attitude from the staff. Thank you Lost Lei!

Went here to celebrate my birthday with friends. It had just recently opened and thought it would be a great place to go for happy hour. We were right! They had 1/2 price drinks till 7 p.m and they were so good! Bartenders were still learning, but had great suggestions on what to try. Will definitely be back next time I'm in Austin!

We asked about ordering and he said you have to go up to the bar to order.  We both got a mai tai, which was ok, listened to some Fergie and Gwen Stefani playing, and were on our way. It wasn't bad, but definitely not like other tiki bars we've been to.
If you love tiki bars this place doesn't disappoint. The selection of rum is great. The drinks are authentic and their tiki mugs are awesome!
